The FBI spent months investigating whether the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee intentionally or negligently mishandled classified information on her personal email account and private server.
One question is whether she mishandled classified information on the servers. As the investigation wound up, Clinton underwent a voluntary     interview with the FBI on Saturday in Washington.
The FBI director pointed out that the probe was tasked with examining whether Clinton or her aides had mishandled classified information either intentionally or in a grossly negligent way.

Comey also broadly criticized the handling of classified information on unclassified email systems at the State Department, saying investigators found evidence that the "security culture" there was "generally lacking in the kind of care for classified information" displayed at other government agencies.

He also said she used email extensively while traveling "in territory of sophisticated adversaries". Experts routinely advise U S government officials not to bring important digital information to countries with a track record of aggressive cyber activity. And since Clinton frequently used her private email while traveling "in the territory of sophisticated adversaries," as Comey put it, the FBI views it as possible that her account was compromised.

Hillary Clinton and her staff were "extremely careless" in handling classified data over a private email server while she was secretary of state, FBI Director James Comey said Tuesday  --   but the FBI is recommending that no charges be brought against her.
He said her staff should have known Clinton's private email was an improper place for classified information, but added there was no evidence anyone had hacked Clinton's communications.

FBI Director James B Comey said Tuesday that his agency will not recommend criminal charges against Hillary Clinton for her use of a private email server as secretary of state but called Clinton and her staff "extremely careless" in handling classified material.

Comey said of the 30, 000 emails that Clinton's team turned over to the State Department, 110 emails in 52 email chains were determined to have contained classified information "at the time they were sent or received," Comey said.
"Our assessment is that, like many email users, Secretary Clinton periodically deleted emails or emails were purged from the system when devices were changed," Comey said.
The FBI found 110 emails in 52 email chains that contained information that was classified at the time the messages were sent, Comey said.

Comey also said that, while the FBI found no direct evidence that Clinton's email was hacked by a foreign party, "it is possible that hostile actors gained access to Secretary Clinton's personal email account".

"With respect to potential computer intrusion by hostile actors, we did not find direct evidence that Secretary Clinton's personal   mail domain in its various configuration since 2009 was hacked successfully. But given the nature of the system and of the actors potentially involved, we assess we would be unlikely to see such direct evidence," Comey said.

He also noted that while the FBI could find no direct evidence of an intrusion into Clinton's server by hostile foreign governments, given that she corresponded with individuals whose accounts were compromised and that the server was not secured by government protections, and that she used her email in hostile foreign territories, "It is possible that hostile actors gained access to Secretary Clinton's email account".
"As the secretary has long said, it was a mistake to use her personal email, and she would not do it again. We are glad that this matter is now resolved," spokesman Brian Fallon said.

In a statement, Hillary Clinton's campaign spokesman Brian Fallon said her team is "pleased that the career officials handling this case have determined that no further action by the Department is appropriate".
